content.question: Ultraviolet (<math alttext="U V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) radiation can damage <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> by breaking weak bonds. Which of the following best explains how this occurs?

choices.label: <math alttext="U V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> radiation disrupts the double helix structure by breaking the covalent bonds between the nitrogenous base pairs.

<math alttext="U V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> radiation disrupts the double helix structure by breaking the hydrogen bonds between the nitrogenous base pairs.

<math alttext="U V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> radiation is able to break <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> strands in two by breaking covalent bonds between the sugar-phosphate backbone molecules.

<math alttext="U V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> radiation is able to break <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> strands in two by breaking hydrogen bonds between the sugar-phosphate backbone molecules.

content.answer: <math alttext="U V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> radiation disrupts the double helix structure by breaking the hydrogen bonds between the nitrogenous base pairs.
